title: How playing two left-footed centre-backs sums up Aston Villa’s problems
description: Squad balance and depth remains in question at Villa – as the struggles of Torres and Mings in defence against Brentford showed
content:
Pau Torres and Tyrone Mings started together in central defence.

It had been a long time coming, given their respective injuries and the general reticence to combine two left-footed defenders until the perfect moment and within the perfect structure.

There had to be a degree of care and meticulous planning. Outwardly, the perception is that two left-footed central defenders are too awkward. They lead to breakdowns in possession and allow opponents to press easily, knowing the limitations of one defender playing on their weaker side. In other words, they can become a sitting duck.

But, after right-footed centre-back Ezri Konsa’s red card against Newcastle United, this was to be the moment.

Against Fulham in February 2024, when Aston Villa played with Torres and another left-footer in Clement Lenglet, Unai Emery intelligently adjusted the system to foil Fulham’s press, including a specific goal-kick routine. But this season is different.

Villa are thinner and seemingly short of impetus and evolution in their play. A lack of freshness to the squad, fundamentally caused by various financial restrictions, is an issue well-publicised but it was fiercely evident against Brentford. Internally, players and staff accept the team needs a refresh of some kind.

Seven players who started on Saturday worked with Emery’s predecessor, Steven Gerrard, and there were four academy players on the bench. Anti-Premier League chants continued from the away end during the first half and frustrations simmered throughout.

The 1-0 defeat was what Villa deserved and duly got. Starved of pace and, in Emery’s words, “intensity”, the loss accentuated the obvious tactical imbalances within the side. The left-footed centre-backs exemplified this, at fault for the only goal of the game and setting the sense of awkwardness from back to front.

“We aren’t creating clear chances, we’re not opening up teams and players are not playing at their best,” said John McGinn afterwards, typically frank. “It is very early on, we can’t panic, but we need to improve, definitely.”

A disconnect ran throughout the side and Brentford’s goal was the punishment. One simple ball upfield from goalkeeper Caoimhin Kelleher caused hesitation between Mings and Torres.

The former, playing on the right side, did not know his whereabouts and was caught a step behind Igor Thiago, who won the first contact. It may have only been a split second initially but it was telling.

Torres, a defender who Emery admitted at the end of last season has “difficulties in defensive duels” has never been the fleetest of foot and was horribly exposed, lunging in and failing to stop Dango Ouattara breaking through.

It was peculiar to watch the left-footed centre-backs operate as if they were fine and one of them playing on their weaker foot was not inhibited. In truth, it was clearly the opposite. It was also peculiar to watch Villa, without a right-winger, play as if they had a winger and do that precise job, like McGinn did.

In the aftermath, Emery stated McGinn is not a player to create “individual actions man to man”, instead opening “spaces for our right-back.” So to do this, McGinn required a right-back to overlap outside of him.

Here, however, Matty Cash’s remit was clear: to stay in a back three, enabling Mings to move centrally and be more favourable for his left-footed passing.

This was an alarming performance, even if it came early in the campaign. The flaws shown against Newcastle United seven days earlier — an unevenness in width, pace and insertion — were even more striking in west London.

Emery did not compensate for the absence of a traditional winger by deploying a wing-back system in possession, pushing Cash higher to provide width and rolling Boubacar Kamara into the right centre-back space. This might have solved Mings’ issues and helped McGinn to be more comfortable in his remit.

Kamara pulled up with a hamstring issue as Brentford celebrated Ouattara’s goal and in his place came Emiliano Buendia, the player Villa wanted to sell and still could be sold. Donyell Malen, a pacey wide forward whose introduction would enable McGinn to move centrally, stayed glued to the bench.

Amadou Onana remained but, having been trailed as a third centre-back in pre-season to do a similar role as Kamara should Villa be without a right-footed centre-back, Emery decided to keep him slugging away in midfield.

Ironically, in the friendly against Marseille, Onana’s incisive pass in the third centre-back position led to McGinn’s goal, back when the Scotland international was central and Jacob Ramsey was still in the Midlands.

Both centre-backs were dragged into wide areas against Brentford: Mings onto his right foot and Torres where his lack of mobility would be isolated. One of several injury-enforced breaks gave Emery time to speak to the pair, yet nothing, ostensibly, changed.

Villa conceded a long throw-in after Mings and Torres combined to pass and then miscontrolled the ball out of play.

The direct result was another throw hurled into their box with Emiliano Martinez attempting to claim the high ball — something Emery had gestured for earlier in the half. Martinez was knocked to the floor as the ball went into his net. A VAR intervention saved Villa from being two goals down and misery compounded.

Black Sabbath’s ‘Paranoid’ echoed over the speakers as the players trudged down the tunnel at half-time, pre-empting Villa’s full-time emotions. The players had looked ragged, insecure and vulnerable tactically.

The squad’s balance is in question — exemplified by the awkward troubles of Villa’s central defenders.
summary: Aston Villa's performance in a 1-0 defeat to Brentford was highlighted by the team's inability to play two left-footed central defenders, Pau Torres and Tyrone Mings, who started together in central defence. This comes after right-footed centre-back Ezri Konsa was sent off against Newcastle United. The team's performance was criticised for being too awkward and allowing opponents to press easily. Despite this, Unai Emery has acknowledged that the team needs a refresh and is looking to address these issues internally. The lack of freshness to the squad is largely due to financial restrictions and a lack of pace and intensity. The only goal of the game was scored by Brentford's goalkeeper Caoimhin Kelleher, setting up the awkwardness between Mings and Torres.
shortSummary: Aston Villa's decision to combine two left-footed defenders, resulting in a 1-0 loss to Brentford, highlights the team’s struggles with inconsistent play and inconsistent performances.

scraped_sources.text:
The defensive box between the two central defenders and deepest midfielders is the equivalent of Aston Villa’s vertebrae.
Yet key absentees meant Villa’s posture had begun to slump. Injuries to three central defenders called for Pau Torres, who had not started in exactly two months, to return under less-than-ideal circumstances against Fulham.
Advertisement
In a perfect world, Unai Emery would never wish to pick the back four he chose, with two left-footers in central defence considered a “do not touch” option in modern football. Clement Lenglet was loaned in to be a backup to Torres, not to play alongside him.
It is a footballing paradox that two right-footed centre-backs are generally deemed suitable, yet the mere thought of two left-footers induces an overwhelming reluctance from managers.
The view is they look too awkward, leading to structural breakdowns in possession. Opposition forwards find it easier to arch their body shape a certain way when pressing — knowing the limitations of a left-footer being forced onto their weaker foot — and set traps. And to exacerbate ball progression fears, Emery was without his chief midfield anchor Boubacar Kamara, a player who would, ordinarily, drop deeper to conduct play.
Establishing control is the overarching idea of Emery, but Villa have regularly struggled to achieve authority away from home. The most straightforward way to gain the upper hand is through possession; it was why avoiding transitions was in sharp focus against Manchester United and here at Fulham. With a changed centre-back duo and double pivot, effective ball retention was needed more than ever before.
Yet in comparison to other first halves on the road, Villa limited Fulham to few chances and held a degree of control that was influential in the 2-1 victory. A key element to this was Emery offsetting the left-footed centre-back problem while retaining balance.
And much of it had to do with Villa’s goal kicks…
Villa took nine goal kicks in the first half alone, with three different players restarting play. This was a concerted ploy by Emery to jumble the opposition’s press, knowing Fulham pressed man for man from goal kicks.
By having either Emiliano Martinez, Torres or Lenglet each take a goal kick, it meant Fulham’s players could not lock to their direct opponent as quickly, with Villa varying and opening different passing lanes into midfield or out wide.
Fulham’s trigger to press is often when the ball goes to the opposing full-backs. This is because they receive possession with their back against the touchline, limiting the number of passing options they have.
To counteract this, Emery did not just want his goalkeeper taking goal kicks. Instead, Villa were able to slide the first pass to the opposite centre-back not taking the goal kick, changing the angles in how they passed out.
The first goal kick came in the third minute and set the tone. It was taken by Lenglet, who played to Martinez and Fulham were late in shuffling across to Torres.
Torres is the most composed player Villa have in possession and immediately displayed those inherent traits. He chopped inside Bobby De Cordova-Reid and switched the ball out to Matty Cash, stationed on the opposite side. Fulham did not have enough players to press the full-back.
In turn, Villa’s rewired build-up structure took shape. In open play, Cash would tuck in to become a third centre-back, ordered by Emery to take up narrow positions and shift Lenglet centrally. This helped to compensate for the two left-footers, just as Emery outlined in pre-season when he wanted to incorporate Mings and Torres together.
“In our structure, sometimes we are building up with three or four players, using different players but all under the same rule,” explained Emery post-match. “Today, Cash tried to give balance with Leon Bailey getting wide of him.”
On occasion, Lenglet would stand on the ball, waiting for the shape to change. Here, he finds himself in an uncomfortable right centre-back position but pauses for eight seconds. This gives time for Cash to come short, receiving the ball to play forward.
By Cash inverting, the width from the right came from Bailey.
Crucially, Emery knew Fulham could easily apply pressure on Villa with their press if players stayed in fixed positions. Instead, he required intelligent rotations from goal kicks, designed to drag players’ direct markers — such as Joao Palhinha on Youri Tielemans — into unfamiliar areas.
In the example below, Martinez throws the ball for Lenglet to take. Lenglet’s position was precise from every goal kick, always standing on the right corner of the six-yard box, with Torres slightly wider. This was to enable Torres, the more progressive player who was on his comfortable foot, to open expansive passing lanes and for build-up patterns to be shaped by his distribution.
Lenglet passes to Cash, who has again dropped deep to offer a short option.
As the ball is played, Tielemans sprints to the right, offering width outside of the full-back. Due to Fulham’s man-to-man marking scheme, this drags Palhinha across the pitch, creating space inside the pitch for either the next pass or a midfield run.
Variation from goal kicks became an underlying theme. Before Villa’s third goal kick, Martinez decides to kick long. He gestures for Jacob Ramsey to drop deeper, freeing up space for a pass to go over his head and towards Ollie Watkins in the left channel.
An offshoot of an aggressive man-marking ploy is the susceptibility of being caught one-on-one in defence. Pertinently, Torres proved adept in whipping channel passes for the in-to-out run of Watkins, with Issa Diop the designated marker.
The match-up appeared unsuccessful in the first half, with Watkins needing treatment after Diop’s robust challenge, but sticking to the plan culminated in Watkins’ second goal having initially drawn Diop towards him.
Note how Tielemans’ head is already swivelling before he takes his first touch, anticipating where the next pass should be played. Watkins pushes off his left leg and spins behind Diop, who is square on and unable to shift his body quickly enough. Tielemans finds Watkins’ run, who lashes past Bernd Leno.
Goal kicks and a subtle change of shape were symbolic of the performance. Emery found creative solutions to overcome Villa’s recent adversity.

Eighteen months later than planned, Unai Emery admitted what most had been wondering.
“I would like to play with both players in the starting XI,” the Aston Villa manager said, when asked by The Athletic if (and how) Tyrone Mings and Pau Torres could play together. “The structure we have to create with both needs time, time practising in training sessions, time maybe practising in official matches.”
Advertisement
The logic is sound and in theory, pairing two central defenders seems straightforward. Mings and Torres are highly experienced, possessing contrasting but complementary skill sets — so what is the issue?
In the simplest terms: they are both left-footed.
Highly skilled left-footed centre-backs are esoteric, owing to their capacity to open up different passing lanes and enabling coaches to counteract an opponent’s press. They are crucial to build-up play, often having the most touches and passes of any player and, consequently, proving the most progressive vehicle of attack. Torres, for example, ranks in the top four per cent of defenders from Europe’s top five leagues for progressive carries (1.59 per 90 minutes).
Mings is a solid passer, though not as adept as Torres. Mings has alternative strengths the Spain international cannot match. He is Villa’s best in-box defender and aerial presence, relishing the more abrasive parts of the job. This should not detract from Mings’s overall ability, having made impressive strides in his work with the ball.
Integrating Torres and Mings into an effective system requires deep thinking from Emery. Moving either to the right carried risk because the perception is that a left-footer looks too awkward and can be pressed easily, with opposition forwards forcing them to kick with their weaker foot.
The question of how to fit the pair together without taking away their natural attributes was at the forefront of Emery’s 2023 pre-season planning. He had outlined to Mings that he would remain a key starter following Torres’ arrival and design a system to incorporate both. This eased any concerns Mings was being replaced, particularly after receiving interest from another Premier League club.
This would all prove futile. Mings was injured 30 minutes into the opening day fixture of the 2023-24 campaign away at Newcastle United, with Torres replacing him. The England international spent 445 days recovering from a ruptured anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and cartilage damage.
GO DEEPER
Inside Tyrone Mings' 445-day road to recovery
Only now has Emery signalled for a return to the initial thinking. Mings has proven his form and fitness to coaching staff with a player-of-the-match performance in the 3-1 victory against Brentford and nullified any lingering doubts that he would not come back the same player. At his best, Mings significantly improves a defence that has been porous in his absence — not helped by Torres’ blind spot against physical strikers — and shown a weakness in defending set plays.
Advertisement
“I am very happy now we have both players,” said Emery. “Mings played a fantastic match against Brentford. He had played other matches where he felt comfortable but Brentford was the match he played even better and got confidence to feel comfortable.
“Pau Torres is helping us a lot in the style we have. They are different (players). Mings is a little bit stronger in everything and Pau is a little bit (stronger) in the build-up and the characteristics he has are high quality. Both can improve, like Mings in his build-up and Pau is making an effort to be stronger in duels.”
This month, Emery dusted off his plans from the 2023 pre-season, offering indications he is prepared to change Villa’s structure to select both. This would have a knock-on effect on other areas of the team — for what Villa gain by adding a defender, they lose somewhere else on the pitch. How to strike the right balance continues to be a head-scratcher for Emery.
How the season has developed might have accelerated Emery’s idea of playing Torres and Mings. The justification for a tactical tweak has grown stronger with every passing week, partly because of form but considering the positions Villa are vulnerable in also adds weight to the case for change.
Emery has strength in depth in central defence, while his options in wide areas — and their productivity — have been under-par. Villa have a shortage of wingers and the ones they do have, such as Leon Bailey and Jaden Philogene, are enduring difficult campaigns.
In turn, changing to a wing-back formation means a third central defender, providing a neat solution to the Mings/Torres conundrum.
The first discernible change came in the 3-2 victory away at RB Leipzig. Bailey was injured and, on paper, Matty Cash had taken his place on the right wing.
Intriguingly, there was a noticeable shift in structure when the game began. Ezri Konsa resembled a right central defender in a back three, with Diego Carlos stationed between him and Torres, who was on the left.
Emery would constantly instruct Cash as to his positioning throughout:
In a pronounced back three, Cash and Lucas Digne were high and wide on opposite flanks, serving as wing-backs in a newly comprised 3-4-2-1.
The adjustment in build-up patterns ambushed Leipzig and gave Villa immediate control. As is customary with all Red Bull teams, Leipzig pressed out of a narrow 4-2-2-2 shape yet could not get near Villa’s players because of the width supplied by the wing-backs. This allowed regular switches of play and a perennial out-ball.
Digne and Cash found themselves on the same line as Villa’s No 10s and glued to either touchline.
Leipzig’s narrow back four was pulled from side to side, with John McGinn’s goal coming from a Cash cross. The move started after the wing-back had broken out of a defensive position.
As soon as Villa turned the ball over, Cash sprinted forward, with his positioning comparable to a right-winger.
The system offered flexibility. Cash and Digne switched to traditional full-backs without the ball and moved Villa into a 5-3-2 shape.
“After the injury to Bailey and Philogene is still in a process, I decided to use Cash playing as a full-back defending low but attacking high and wide,” said Emery in his post-match press conference. “He has the potential to do it. He played at the beginning of his career like a winger and today he worked fantastic.”
Advertisement
Emery’s usual build-up schemes are designed to unlock the left-back in high areas. In possession, they become a quasi-winger, while the right-back tucks in to form a back three and take up a more conservative full-back position. This is demonstrated in the contrasting touchmaps for Digne (at left-back) and Cash (at right-back) this season.
Digne is tasked with sprinting upfield when a move develops and crossing in advanced areas.
Cash, meanwhile, receives possession in deeper areas and his opportunities to go forward are more sporadic.
Villa were impressive against Leipzig and had Mings been picked, he would have likely replaced Carlos as the middle centre-back.
Four days later, Mings was supposed to start at Nottingham Forest in place of Torres as the left centre-back. Villa operated within the same system, but Emery was set to take a horses-for-courses approach, with Mings and Carlos physically more suited to play against Chris Wood, who was up front for Forest.
Although he was named in the starting XI, Mings had been feeling unwell all day and in the warm-up, accepted a sickness bug had got the better of him. Torres was drafted in.
This did not perturb Villa’s strategy, however, with Cash staying high. Increased width meant Villa’s No 10s could start inside the pitch and between the lines, as Morgan Rogers does here:
“Time” is the buzzword and response from Emery when asked about the riddle of blending two left-footed, but very different, centre-backs. Though the idea has not been put to the test under competition yet, Emery’s intentions are clear — not to disturb Villa’s overarching principles, only strengthen them.
(Top photo: Torres, left, and Mings are set to play more together. Getty Images)

Another tifo cascaded from the Holte End before kick-off.
It was Unai Emery smiling and clapping, with his players in the background. Above, the caption: “No limits to our dreams.”
The message was meant to inspire and show that, under manager Emery, Aston Villa have immeasurably raised the bar of their expectations. Yet, at the same time, the tifo jarred.
Advertisement
Below the text and just behind Emery’s head on the banner was Jacob Ramsey. The tifo had been made before the club agreed to let their homegrown lad, born six miles from Villa Park, join Saturday’s opponents. Post-match, Newcastle United’s manager Eddie Howe called Ramsey an “outstanding player”. After all, he was soon going to be theirs.
Fundamentally, Ramsey’s departure is a representation of how Villa’s dreams are being limited or, at the very least, curbed. The 24-year-old was an asset Villa had to sell as a result of various financial restrictions, all blessed with their own acronym.
This has been the summer of (financial) discontent; a subject so evident and stifling that Emery had no choice but to refer to it in his programme notes. His words, as it happened, contradicted the tifo’s message.
“We cannot avoid that the summer has been challenging because the financial rules were conditioning our investment in the squad,” he wrote. “Financial control rules came to football to avoid bankruptcies and payment defaults with a good purpose.
“But as professionals we should review it, as this good tool will become a limitation for clubs that are doing good management, who’ll never be allowed to dream and get higher goals because the revenue, key for these financial rules, needs time to come to reality after sporting success.”
The dreams Emery has fostered since his arrival in November 2022 have endured a reality check this summer. Instead of strengthening a squad that only missed out on Champions League football on goal difference, Villa’s focus has centred on complying with UEFA’s squad cost rules (SCR), reducing a wage bill that previously accounted for 91 per cent of overall revenue down to, at most, 70 per cent.
Villa are a victim of their success. They are entering their third successive season of participating in European competition. UEFA rules state clubs can lose no more than €60million (£51.6m; $70.1m) over that period, plus a possible €10m per year if European football’s governing body deems them to be in a ‘good’ financial state.
UEFA’s ‘football earnings rule’ is a tighter version of the Premier League’s profit and sustainability rules (PSR), which permits losses of up to £105m ($142m) across such a period.
Anyone under the assumption they could forget the acronyms and financial red tape for 90 minutes for the first league fixture of the campaign would have been disappointed. A day usually soaked in optimism only served to underline those concerns.
With Newcastle the better side, albeit painfully short of a centre-forward, both sides played within themselves. This was not a day for players with a spring in their step or a game to welcome new faces. Marco Bizot was Villa’s best player and the only summer signing to feature, due to Emiliano Martinez’s one-game suspension. Bizot’s acquisition as deputy goalkeeper may be the only positional upgrade at Villa this summer.
Advertisement
As the second half meandered until Ezri Konsa’s sending off, both sets of supporters were united in their frustrations. A catalogue of chants echoed around Villa Park, all critical of the Premier League. Claims of corruption and sheer disdain for PSR were part of the playlist. Two fanbases found mutual ground, sympathetic to the other’s situation, with Newcastle previously unable to sign a senior player for three consecutive windows and Villa suffering similar inhibitions this summer.
Villa’s window was always going to be tough. Senior figures told The Athletic at the end of May that incomings were low down the list of priorities, with the primary concern being to remedy financial pressures.
Unavoidably, though, it has left Villa undercooked and uninspiring, as evidenced in Saturday’s goalless draw.
This was only “day one”, as Emery puts it, of a 38-match campaign. The road ahead is long. Yet the general flatness was an extension of Villa’s summer. Zero shots in the first half did not enchant a Villa Park crowd that is normally in thrall to this Emery vintage.
As their manager voiced in the aftermath, it was concerning how many duels Villa lost in the first half. They were fortunate not to concede early on. The haywire passing — at one stage, their pass accuracy percentage was 15 percentage points lower than Newcastle’s — was not in keeping with the on-ball precision for which Villa have been recognised.
The weight of evidence indicates that Emery’s side, in defiance of their ongoing challenges, will not collapse completely because of an inherent robustness. Even when down to 10 men, Villa were well organised and negated Newcastle. They are now 22 competitive games unbeaten in all competitions at home — their longest run since 1977 (24 games) — showing the “consistency” Emery is at pains to relay in most press conferences.
Advertisement
This was a goalless draw devoid of entertainment and quality, but revealing in what it lacked. For Newcastle, it was Alexander Isak. For Villa, it was collective inspiration, usually found in the transfer market. Both teams have similar ambitions — they have broken into the top six but want to do so regularly. They have owners willing to spend but are stunted by PSR.
The upshot is palpable, none more so than for the adults who paid £77 to sit in the Holte End or those in the Doug Ellis or Trinity Stand, where tickets could range up to £82. The squeeze is on and if you are not a traditional ‘Big Six’ club, a bottleneck approaches. Those with revenues not at the requisite level will have to check their aspirations.
This summer has been a paradox. Turbulent, yet stuck in a state of inertia, fighting off possible sanctions and regression on the pitch.
Villa will dream as long as Emery is there, but those dreams are being disrupted by the stresses that disturb a good night’s sleep.
(Top photo: Michael Steele/Getty Images)

“Sometimes, yes, but it depends,” replied Unai Emery, when The Athletic asked whether his Aston Villa side lacked width during Saturday’s stalemate against visitors Newcastle United in both sides’ first game of the new Premier League season.
An imbalance has emerged: Villa have a cluster of attacking midfielders and a scarcity of archetypal wingers. The only specialist in the first-team squad was Leon Bailey, who departed for Italian side Roma this week on a season-long loan.
Advertisement
They could even be adding to their central playmakers via a reunion with Marco Asensio.
The Paris Saint-Germain attacker, who made 21 appearances for Villa after joining on loan in February, would join Morgan Rogers, John McGinn, Youri Tielemans and Emiliano Buendia as attacking-midfield options. Emery also reckons summer acquisition Evann Guessand, who has mostly played as a wide forward in his career so far, has the skill set to play as a “No 10”.
Emery’s attacking principles revolve around two No 10s when in possession, a way of playing that’s designed to create central overloads. Villa rely heavily on offensive output through the middle of the pitch, with only Chelsea funnelling a greater proportion of their attacks centrally last season (31 per cent and 32 per cent of attacks respectively).
The Spanish manager’s build-up style is also based on lopsided, asymmetrical full-backs, with the left-back high and the right-back tucking in as a third central defender.
Width is delivered from the left-back (in the image below, it’s Lucas Digne) and right-winger (Bailey), enabling the ostensible “left-winger” to operate as a second attacking midfielder. Before he also left the club this week, in a £39million move to Newcastle, this would be Jacob Ramsey’s role.
This produces a discernible shape in every game — a four-man ‘box’ midfield aims to progress the ball upfield, with the two forwards up ahead giving Villa six players in the central area of the pitch.
Football, though, is transitory. It requires evolution, as opponents will learn ways to negate vital components of your plan. As Villa found out in important matches last season, such as the FA Cup semi-final defeat against Crystal Palace, teams are no longer willing to step out, press Emery’s back line and allow space to open up in midfield. Opponents are comfortable sitting in a defensive block and blocking passing lanes in midfield.
Advertisement
So the focus now magnifies on Villa’s lack of width.
The passage that contributed to Ezri Konsa’s red card in that 0-0 draw with Newcastle on Saturday can be traced back to the absence of a wide player.
Below, Villa lose possession after Matty Cash’s cross is cut out, allowing Newcastle to transition. Ordinarily, Emery would prefer a winger in that crossing position rather than right-back Cash.
His recovery pace — similar to how Pep Guardiola used Kyle Walker at Manchester City — is imperative in guarding against counter-attacks. The Poland international has been the subject of interest from previous club Nottingham Forest, who are exploring a deal to sign him.
In an ideal world, Cash would remain behind the ball, in turn improving Villa’s rest defence — a tactical term that assesses a team’s structure and effectiveness, should they lose possession. Unsurprisingly, after the match, Emery was critical of his players’ ability to curtail Newcastle’s breakaways, explaining that the opportunities conceded stemmed from transitions.
Yet in this instance, Villa did not have sufficient numbers behind the ball, with their central defenders caught high.
Anthony Gordon raced away, and Konsa felt he had no choice but to bring down his England team-mate.
Villa’s sparse width was telling and figured in a broadly flat opening-day display, despite showing spirited resolve to earn a point with 10 men for the final 25 minutes.
A wide player is on the list of priorities as we approach the final week of the summer transfer window but, frankly, Emery’s attacking strategy will invariably be built on their No 10s.
Each one of his options sits in a strange predicament. Ramsey’s departure leaves Villa short of one of their best ball carriers, even if his sale was described as “needs must” by a Villa source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity as they are not authorised to, in fighting potential UEFA financial sanctions.
Advertisement
Rogers is Villa’s premium attacking midfielder, though he sustained an ankle injury in the friendly against Roma two weeks ago and is still working to return to full fitness. There is an acceptance internally that much of the attacking burden this campaign, owing to a trimmed squad, will rest on his shoulders. Only Mohamed Salah (18), Jacob Murphy (12) and Anthony Elanga (11) provided more Premier League assists than Rogers’ 10 last season.
The 23-year-old’s versatility and varied skill set are essential to Villa. He can cover four positions and is on a low salary, relative to his standing. This is partly why, as The Athletic reported in July, Villa intend to offer Rogers improved terms at the end of this transfer window, reflecting his status as a key player and fending off several Premier League admirers. On Tuesday evening, he was named the Professional Footballers’ Association (PFA) Young Player of the Year.
While six-time England senior international Rogers was increasingly used off the right last season — due to a combination of a lack of wide options and Emery wanting a clutch of players who drift centrally in his line-up — there is hope that he plays either directly behind the centre-forward or off the left, where he can cut inside onto his stronger foot.
McGinn, like Rogers, is usually deployed centrally or on either flank. Villa are also planning contract negotiations with their club captain, following strong summer interest from Everton. It can be revealed that Villa turned down a formal offer at the end of July, contrary to reports of a bid being made this month. Scoring just one league goal, McGinn’s attacking returns diminished last season, but Villa had already made clear that he would be staying. Though the Scot turns 31 in October, he is considered an integral part of Emery’s plans.
Then there is Buendia.
He was initially in the group of players Villa wanted to move on during this window, also comprising Roma loanee Bailey, Alex Moreno, who is close to joining Girona, and Leander Dendoncker, who signed for Real Oviedo this week. But after an impressive pre-season, Emery sees value in Buendia, with the 28-year-old in better shape and more attuned to the required intensity.
Buendia is keen to stay, but his future will remain uncertain until the window shuts on the evening of Monday, September 1.
Even when facing restrictions, Emery is not a manager to sit on his hands.
This relates to Asensio. Preferably, Villa would have activated their buy option at the end of his six-month loan earlier in the summer, but their headroom in the Premier League’s profit and sustainability rules (PSR) was extremely tight then. Senior figures travelled to Madrid in June to explain the club’s distribution of finances to Asensio’s representatives and why they could not afford the required package at the time. Should funds be available towards the end of the summer window, circumstances may change.
Asensio is still at PSG. Fenerbahce came closest to signing him but failed to agree a price with the European champions. The 29-year-old Spain international remains hopeful that Villa, in the final days of the market, will become an active possibility again, with his agent Jorge Mendes tasked with arranging a deal. It is not thought that personal terms would be a problem.
Attacking midfielders have long formed Emery’s style.
